fields.title: Historica Association of Tanzania
fields.subtitle: HAT welcomes you to Participate to this years conference
fields.description: The Historical Association of Tanzania is a trusted voice advocating for history education, the professional work of historians, and the critical role of historical thinking in public life. It is one of the oldest academic associations in East Africa. It was founded in 1966 by members of the Department of History at Dar es Salaam University College of East Africa. By 1974, it had branches in many secondary schools and colleges throughout Tanzania. In addition to hosting seminars and conferences for historians, the association played a crucial role in producing and disseminating historical knowledge across the country. The about us also include officers or management team (president, vice president, general secretary, deputy secretary and treasurer) ; immediate past president and the list of past officers).

fields.title: Welcome Message from HAT President
fields.subtitle: Dr Maxmillian J. Chuhila the president of historical association of Tanzania
fields.description: Dear Members, I am delighted to welcome you to our website. Our Association continues to be a beacon for the development of historical knowledge within and beyond the borders of the United Republic of Tanzania. From humble beginnings, we aspire to grow to greater heights of influence in the study of history and its ancillary disciplines through an interdisciplinary approach. Since our reorganisation in 2015, we have collectively achieved several milestones. One of the most notable has been the organisation of annual conferences and meetings. These conferences, which are usually held at different higher education institutions on a rotating basis, have raised awareness of our activities among members and the public over the years and thereby fostering a pan-African approach in the study of African history. We are introducing several key initiatives to enrich member’s experience. These include the launch of a website and social media accounts on Facebook and Twitter/X to make the Association more visible and engage with the public and our members. Our new digital platforms will increase connectivity, enabling more robust discussions and easier access to resources. Your feedback has been invaluable in shaping these initiatives and I encourage you to continue to share your thoughts. Our success depends on the active engagement and contributions of every member, and your participation is vital as we navigate the evolving landscape in academia especially when working from the global south. Together we can achieve greater heights. Let us continue to support each other, foster innovation and build a community where every member feels valued and empowered. I am excited about what we will achieve in the coming years and look forward to working with you to reach new heights. As a non-governmental, non-profit organisation, our activities must be self-funded. Each of us should feel obliged to support the activities of the HAT through your annual membership fees and participation in conferences and occasional symposia. We appeal to friends and well-wishers in academia and industry to kindly support our activities. As we develop outreach programmes in schools and colleges across the country, we will need more funding to achieve our goals. Membership fees alone will not be enough. Please contact us at any time if you have an idea for a fundraising strategy or a suggestion for an effective activity that HAT can undertake. Warm regards, Maxmillian Julius Chuhila, PhD. HAT President.

fields.title: About Us
fields.description: The Historical Association of Tanzania is a trusted voice advocating for history education, the professional work of historians, and the critical role of historical thinking in public life. It is one of the oldest academic associations in East Africa. It was founded in 1966 by members of the Department of History at Dar es Salaam University College of East Africa. By 1974, it had branches in many secondary schools and colleges throughout Tanzania. In addition to hosting seminars and conferences for historians, the association played a crucial role in producing and disseminating historical knowledge across the country. fields.title: Attend to Our Annual Conference
fields.description: Don't miss this year's HAT Annual Conference, dedicated to the legacy of postcolonial historiography and its relevance to nation-building and development in Tanzania and beyond. This is your chance to engage in critical discussions on Tanzania’s rich history, its contributions to liberation struggles, regional peacekeeping, and its role during the Cold War.

fields.name: Dr Abdallah R. Mkumbukwa
fields.description: Dr Abdallah R. Mkumbukwa is the General Secretary of the Historical Association of Tanzania (HAT). He is a social scientist, environmentalist and historian. Dr Mkumbukwa is a Lecturer and Dean of the School of Natural and Social Sciences at the State University of Zanzibar (SUZA). He is also a member of various boards. His research interests and publications include the history of health and healing in Africa, environmental history, heritage studies and the history of childhood. His research and teaching draws on the integration of social and natural sciences in historical perspectives. Dr Mkumbukwa is the author of a book: Socio-economic Change and Disease: The Spread of Malaria and its Control in Zanzibar - Tanzania, 1915 - 2000, and he was a team member in writing a book entitled: Historia ya Muungano wa Tanganyika na Zanzibar, organised by the Office of the Vice President of the United Republic of Tanzania and the Office of the Second Vice President of the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar. He has also published on the history of wildlife conservation policy in Tanzania and on the conservation of marine resources in Zanzibar.

fields.name: Josephine Francis Sanga
fields.description: Josephine Sanga is the HAT Project Officer. She is a dedicated and result-oriented professional with background in economics and statistics. She graduated from the University of Dar es Salaam with a Bachelor Degree of Arts in Economics and Statistics. Over the years she has demonstrated a strong commitment to professional growth and excellence through various roles. Some of the roles included; operations support, management and leadership skills, financial management and project implementation, accounting and statistical analysis. In her role as a project officer she is responsible for the general administration and coordination of HAT activities including updating information on social media and website, corresponding on behalf on the Executive Committee, preparing financial reconciliations and quarterly reports among other roles. Email:

fields.name: Dr Samwel S. Mhajida
fields.description: Dr Samwel S. Mhajida is the Deputy Secretary of the Historical Association of Tanzania (HAT). He is a Senior Lecturer at the College of Education, University of Dar es Salaam. As deputy secretary, he is actively involved with the HAT in organising meetings, preparing documents and chairing a committee on research and publication. Academically, he is the author of a book, The Collapse of a Pastoral Economy: The Datoga of Central and Northern Tanzania, 1830s-2000s (Goettingen University Press, 2019), and one of the authors of an edited volume (by Cynthia Holder Rich), Christian Zionism in Africa (Lexington Books/Fortress Academic, 2020). Apart from these books, he has also published several journal articles on ethnic history, gendered studies, university education and currently he is working on an edited book project titled ‘The Cambridge History of African Political Thought’, where he focuses on the Jewish Political Thought in Contemporary Africa. Apart from these academic engagements, he is an associate editor-in-chief of Zamani: A Journal of African Historical Studies, of the Department of History of the University of Dar es Salaam.

fields.name: Ms. Emma A. Minja
fields.description: Ms Emma Minja is the Vice President of the Historical Association of Tanzania (HAT). She is a self-motivated academic, currently working as an Assistant Lecturer at the Mwalimu Nyerere Memorial Academy (MNMA) in Dar es salaam, Tanania. She is currently a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Bonn in Germany where she is working in a collaborative research network under the auspices of a project entitled: 'Future Rural Africa'. Her research interests include rural transformation, land use, environmental history and the intersection of science and technology. As Vice President of HAT, Emma leads on publicity and membership and works with the Treasurer and the Project Officer on financial matters.

fields.name: Dr Maxmillian J. Chuhila
fields.description: Dr Maxmillian J. Chuhila is the President of the Historical Association of Tanzania (HAT). He is responsible for the general running of the association in collaboration with the other members of the executive committee (EXCOM). He chairs all EXCOM meetings and the meetings of the governing board. Dr Chuhila is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of History at the University of Dar es Salaam. He holds a PhD from the University of Warwick, a Master of Arts in History and a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Dar es Salaam - Tanzania. He teaches Theory of History and various thematic and regional courses. Dr Chuhila has been involved in academic leadership for the past ten years. He has served as the General Secretary of the University of Dar es Salaam Academic Staff Assembly (UDASA), 2018 - 2022, Deputy Secretary of the Historical Association of Tanzania (HAT), 2018 - 2023, General Secretary of the Academic Staff Association of Public Universities and Colleges of Tanzania (ASAPUCT), 2022 - 2024. In addition to his academic leadership, Dr Chuhila researches and publishes in areas such as rural and urban transformation, land use, environmental history and theory of history theory, among others. He also supervises postgraduate students in these areas.

fields.name: Dr Yustina Samwel Komba
fields.description: Dr Yustina S. Komba is the Treasurer of the Historical Association of Tanzania (HAT). She is a Lecturer at the Department of History, University of Dar es Salaam. As HAT Treasurer, she works on resource mobilisation, fundraising and financial management. Her academic research interests include economic and business history, social and gender history. Some of her works include: “A Socio-economic History of Coffee Production in Mbinga District, Tanzania, c.1920 – 2015” (2021) and “The Role of the Colonial State in the Spread and Strengthening of Christianity in Colonial Tanganyika, Circa 1890–1961”, Journal of Religion in Africa, (2024).
